Ben Maurer wrote:
> Btw, on the topic of JUnit3 tool compat: is it possible to make is so
> we don't have to write:
>
>         public static junit.framework.Test suite()
>         {
>                 return new
> junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter(HashtableTest.class);
>         }
>
> *if* we are using the JUnit4 version of the tools. The logic could be
> something like:
>
> if (I am asked to run a junit3 test on something) {
>    if (any methods have the @Test annotation) {
>       use junit4 behavior
>    }
>
>    fallback
> }
We could look at it.  However, the logic would be more likely that it 
would try every possible way to run the class as a JUnit 3 test, and 
then try JUnit 4 as a fallback (since not all JUnit 4 test classes have 
@Test).
> > > When you have an expected exception, and another one gets thrown, the
> > > error trace doesn't contain the bad exception. You only get:
> > >
> > > java.lang.AssertionError: Unexpected exception,
> > > expected<java.util.NoSuchElementException> but
> > > was<java.lang.NullPointerException>
> > >
> > > Having the trace of the bad exception would help TAs debug student
> code.
> > That's a good idea.  We'll try to have that in the next release.
>
> Thanks. This also comes up with timeouts. It'd be really cool to have
> a stacktrace from where the thread was hung.
Agreed.
> Oh, and since I'm talking to another person from a school with a great
> CS dept ;-), I'm really interested in writing good docs for students
> on how to write test suites, especially for data structures (the focus
> of the 15-211 course). I have something that I hacked up for our first
> homework, however, this kind of thing would be great to make into a
> tutorial that could be used by other classes.
Lecture 11 from MIT 6.170 is the best pre-prepared doc I know of around 
here:

http://ocw.mit.edu/OcwWeb/Electrical-Engineering-and-Computer-Science/6-170Laboratory-in-Software-EngineeringFall2001/LectureNotes/index.htm

I'd be very interested in your materials, as well, if they're publicly 
available.  Thanks,
